HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 19, 1926.

GENTLEMEN
The approaching examinations impel] us to discuss the
Honor System and "The Code of a Gentleman." For years there
has been scarcely a complaint about the conduct of undergraduate exercises, tests and examinations. There have been few
exceptions to the general rule of rectitude. All violations of tile
system have been rigidly dealt with; the University has been
fortunate in its affairs of undergraduate honor.
It is the duty of every loyal Hopkins man, every student at
the University to remember the traditions of the Honor System.
Every man is considered a gentleman, and we believe that there
are few,if any, who cannot be placed in that category. It is up
to the individual student to maintain the standard of morality
in scholastic work of which the University is so justly proud;
it is the duty of each student to guard himself, to disregard
his neighbor,—to pay strict attention to himself only. As we go
into the dreaded examination we must resolve that we will
maintain the fair name of the Honor System.
And when we finally sign the pledge, "I have neither given
nor received help on this examination," we will be able to do
so with a clear conscience.

COURTESY
While the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER did not attend the
Student Assembly last Thursday, he understands, from reliable
sources, that the conduct of the students was nothing short of
atrocious, that it was the height of rudeness, that any outside
spectator would have gained the impression that politeness was
foreign to the Hopkins' nature. Such a tendency is to be deprecated. We.believe that one of the few traditions of this University which really carries the force of a la* is the custom of
unfailing courtesy.
When a speaker consents to address an assembly of stu' dents at Hopkins he naturally expects to receive a quiet and
courteous reception from his audience. He must be greatly
surprised when the undergraduates are loud and noisy through'out the entire speech. He will go to other places, and with
him he will carry the story of his reception at Hopkins, he
will point to this University as an institution where hospitality
is unknown, a place to be avoided.
It is up to the students to maintain the reputation of
• Hopkins, it is their duty to enforce the rules of hospitality.
The NEWS-LETTER hopes that' such occurrences as that of last
Thursday will be avoided in the future.

The question is sometimes asked: Where do
young men get when
they enter a large industrial
organization? Have they opportunity to exercise creative
talents? Orare theyforcedinto
narrow grooves?
This series of advertisements throws light on these
questions. Each advertiselent
takes up the record ofa college
man who came with the
Westinghouse Company within the past ten years, after
graduation.

commending quotation from the
Hullaballoo that, "Two games
were played with Virginia . .
—and ...they sham:v.4 up better thL
one could have expected."
But the sport was not to last
long at the southern University.
The spring of 1905 saw the Virginians playing only two games
and in these games they were able
to score only one marker against
the opposition. Although the team
was organized in 1906 and again
in 1907, no schedule was contracted for either year. When 1908
rolled around the Indian game
seemed to have died a natural
•
death..
Until last spring lacrosse showed no signs of revival in the Charlottesville neighborhood. Under
the guidance of Allen L. Voshell,
a 1925 team was produced and
met the l'Hirondelle team in two
games last spring. The Ruxton
boys won the first game at the
University and the_second at l'Hirondelle. But the neophytes put
up a \Val'Ill argument and lost only
as a result of the greater experience of Euxtonites.
This year the sport has been
fully recognized at Virginia and a
team is being prepared by Coach
Voshell to romp off with a nine
game schedule, two games of which
Will be played in Baltimore with
Johns Hopkins and l'Hirondelle.
The remainder of the schedule has
Hot yet been published.
Coach Voshell, formerly of Hopkins, played here in the years 19141-:). He alternated between the inhome and first attack positions.
During the years in which he
played, the Blue team defeated
Harvard, Cornell, Lehigh, Carlisle,
Swarthmore and Toronto. The
Totonto game that year was a
classic in which Hopkins displayed her national supremacy by a
6-0 score.

One Man's Summer Vacation
AVE you ever
seen a man dash
out from a crowd along
a busy street, stop a
runaway team, and save
many from danger?
That wins newspaper
headlines.

H

W. C. Goodwin

But it is only two horses— and it happens once in a blue moon. Every.hour in industry horsepower up into the millions is
tamed to man's control. Runaway apparatus
is instantly checked. Electric controllers
protect operators And the Public. They
safeguard motor and machine.
Thereby hangs a story ofcontrol development, involving W. C. Goodwin, Penn
State 1915. Goodwin spent his summer

vacations tinkering with rotating apparatus
—testing motors and the like. He came
to Westinghouse. Control Engineering
was a magnet for Goodwin, even during
his training period. When the separate
Control Engineering Department was
formed in 1917 Goodwin was in it. Next
he was made, engineer in charge of the
section to design and develop new control equipment. Now he has nine
assistants.

the ship might depend. Goodwin designed
control to do that.

The Control Engineer may be called
upon, as Goodwin was, to meet such an
emergency as this: The war was on.
Battleships were to be propelled by
electricity. Upon the starting, reversing
or stopping of the main propulsion motors
without the loss of a second, the fate of

Control Engineers must know the industry with which they are dealing—steel,
rubber, textile, railroad—and then literally
"fit the control to each order." In seeing the
job through the customer's eyes—Control
Engineers find themselves most at home
with Westinghouse.

Or in industrial application, the Control Engineer may add to human safety,
as Goodwin did. In rubber mills, hands
of operators sometimes are caught between
powerful rollers. A fraction of a second
may mean an arm—or a life. Goodwin's
new combination control apparatus has
greatly reduced the time in stopping the
motor.

Westinghouse

THE BALLY ROTTERS
Editor of the News-Letter.
Dear Sir:
I feel that I must strenuously
protest against the recent vicious
attacks upon derbies. Throwing
snowballs at derby wearers is
nothing short of small town stuff.
On Tuesday I was perniciously
attacked by a number of uncouth
fellows. Really, I was quite upset for the rest of the afternoon.
Oh, dear, what is this younger
generation coming to?
Affectionately,

REGINALD.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 19, 1926.

GENTLEMEN
The approaching examinations impel] us to discuss the
Honor System and "The Code of a Gentleman." For years there
has been scarcely a complaint about the conduct of undergraduate exercises, tests and examinations. There have been few
exceptions to the general rule of rectitude. All violations of tile
system have been rigidly dealt with; the University has been
fortunate in its affairs of undergraduate honor.
It is the duty of every loyal Hopkins man, every student at
the University to remember the traditions of the Honor System.
Every man is considered a gentleman, and we believe that there
are few,if any, who cannot be placed in that category. It is up
to the individual student to maintain the standard of morality
in scholastic work of which the University is so justly proud;
it is the duty of each student to guard himself, to disregard
his neighbor,—to pay strict attention to himself only. As we go
into the dreaded examination we must resolve that we will
maintain the fair name of the Honor System.
And when we finally sign the pledge, "I have neither given
nor received help on this examination," we will be able to do
so with a clear conscience.

COURTESY
While the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER did not attend the
Student Assembly last Thursday, he understands, from reliable
sources, that the conduct of the students was nothing short of
atrocious, that it was the height of rudeness, that any outside
spectator would have gained the impression that politeness was
foreign to the Hopkins' nature. Such a tendency is to be deprecated. We.believe that one of the few traditions of this University which really carries the force of a la* is the custom of
unfailing courtesy.
When a speaker consents to address an assembly of stu' dents at Hopkins he naturally expects to receive a quiet and
courteous reception from his audience. He must be greatly
surprised when the undergraduates are loud and noisy through'out the entire speech. He will go to other places, and with
him he will carry the story of his reception at Hopkins, he
will point to this University as an institution where hospitality
is unknown, a place to be avoided.
It is up to the students to maintain the reputation of
• Hopkins, it is their duty to enforce the rules of hospitality.
The NEWS-LETTER hopes that' such occurrences as that of last
Thursday will be avoided in the future.

The question is sometimes asked: Where do
young men get when
they enter a large industrial
organization? Have they opportunity to exercise creative
talents? Orare theyforcedinto
narrow grooves?
This series of advertisements throws light on these
questions. Each advertiselent
takes up the record ofa college
man who came with the
Westinghouse Company within the past ten years, after
graduation.

commending quotation from the
Hullaballoo that, "Two games
were played with Virginia . .
—and ...they sham:v.4 up better thL
one could have expected."
But the sport was not to last
long at the southern University.
The spring of 1905 saw the Virginians playing only two games
and in these games they were able
to score only one marker against
the opposition. Although the team
was organized in 1906 and again
in 1907, no schedule was contracted for either year. When 1908
rolled around the Indian game
seemed to have died a natural
•
death..
Until last spring lacrosse showed no signs of revival in the Charlottesville neighborhood. Under
the guidance of Allen L. Voshell,
a 1925 team was produced and
met the l'Hirondelle team in two
games last spring. The Ruxton
boys won the first game at the
University and the_second at l'Hirondelle. But the neophytes put
up a \Val'Ill argument and lost only
as a result of the greater experience of Euxtonites.
This year the sport has been
fully recognized at Virginia and a
team is being prepared by Coach
Voshell to romp off with a nine
game schedule, two games of which
Will be played in Baltimore with
Johns Hopkins and l'Hirondelle.
The remainder of the schedule has
Hot yet been published.
Coach Voshell, formerly of Hopkins, played here in the years 19141-:). He alternated between the inhome and first attack positions.
During the years in which he
played, the Blue team defeated
Harvard, Cornell, Lehigh, Carlisle,
Swarthmore and Toronto. The
Totonto game that year was a
classic in which Hopkins displayed her national supremacy by a
6-0 score.

One Man's Summer Vacation
AVE you ever
seen a man dash
out from a crowd along
a busy street, stop a
runaway team, and save
many from danger?
That wins newspaper
headlines.

H

W. C. Goodwin

But it is only two horses— and it happens once in a blue moon. Every.hour in industry horsepower up into the millions is
tamed to man's control. Runaway apparatus
is instantly checked. Electric controllers
protect operators And the Public. They
safeguard motor and machine.
Thereby hangs a story ofcontrol development, involving W. C. Goodwin, Penn
State 1915. Goodwin spent his summer

vacations tinkering with rotating apparatus
—testing motors and the like. He came
to Westinghouse. Control Engineering
was a magnet for Goodwin, even during
his training period. When the separate
Control Engineering Department was
formed in 1917 Goodwin was in it. Next
he was made, engineer in charge of the
section to design and develop new control equipment. Now he has nine
assistants.

the ship might depend. Goodwin designed
control to do that.

The Control Engineer may be called
upon, as Goodwin was, to meet such an
emergency as this: The war was on.
Battleships were to be propelled by
electricity. Upon the starting, reversing
or stopping of the main propulsion motors
without the loss of a second, the fate of

Control Engineers must know the industry with which they are dealing—steel,
rubber, textile, railroad—and then literally
"fit the control to each order." In seeing the
job through the customer's eyes—Control
Engineers find themselves most at home
with Westinghouse.

Or in industrial application, the Control Engineer may add to human safety,
as Goodwin did. In rubber mills, hands
of operators sometimes are caught between
powerful rollers. A fraction of a second
may mean an arm—or a life. Goodwin's
new combination control apparatus has
greatly reduced the time in stopping the
motor.

Westinghouse

THE BALLY ROTTERS
Editor of the News-Letter.
Dear Sir:
I feel that I must strenuously
protest against the recent vicious
attacks upon derbies. Throwing
snowballs at derby wearers is
nothing short of small town stuff.
On Tuesday I was perniciously
attacked by a number of uncouth
fellows. Really, I was quite upset for the rest of the afternoon.
Oh, dear, what is this younger
generation coming to?
Affectionately,

REGINALD.
